description: A possible temple site, where sample trenching in 1989 uncovered numerous 3rd to 4th century coins and stone relief of a Genius, broken in antiquity. The Genius reportedly stood in an aedicula. A relief of a rider-god was re-used and set into the mill in 1853, judging by the inscription.
bibliography: Bagnall-Smith, Jean. “Interim Report on the Votive Material from Romano-Celtic Temple Sites in Oxfordshire,” 1995.
Booth, and Simmonds. “Gill Mill, Ducklington and South Leigh, Oxfordshire. Post-Excavation Assessment and Project Design,” 2011. https://doi.org/10.5284/1023379.
Martyn, Blick, Brindle, and et al. “Gill Mill, Ducklington (Oxfordshire).” The Rural Settlement of Roman Britain: an online resource, 2015. https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449.
